TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by Mr PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE ORG , in proceedings concerning a claim for division of marital property of the applicant and his former wife , PERSON , changed a decision of the lower court given in the case . The court established the value of the property as being PLZ CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL and reduced the payment to be made by the applicant to PERSON from PLZ MONEY to PLZ CARDINAL .

The applicant , considering that the court had committed errors in the calculation of the value of various components of the property , requested the Minister of ORG to lodge an extraordinary appeal against this judgment . The applicant also paid to PERSON the sums fixed by the judgment .

On DATE the Minister of ORG lodged an extraordinary appeal with ORG . The Minister argued that the courts had wrongly calculated the value of the property , in that the value of certain parts of the property had been calculated twice , once as regards their book - keeping value ( i.e. the price to be paid for replacement property items ) and then as regards their market value , and these amounts had been erroneously added . As a result , the applicant was ordered to pay amounts which exceeded by CARDINAL of old zlotys ( PLZ ) the real value of the part of the property for which his former wife had to be reimbursed .

On DATE ORG allowed the extraordinary appeal . As a result , the court quashed the second - instance decision of CARDINAL DATE and amended the decision of the lower court by establishing the value of the property as being approximately PLZ CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL , fixing the share of each spouse at PLZ CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL and reducing the amount that the applicant should have paid to GPE from PLZ MONEY to PLZ CARDINAL . The court considered that the Minister ’s extraordinary appeal was correct in pointing out the calculation errors committed by the lower courts .

The court went on to state that as a result of these errors the applicant ’s obligations had been increased in a manner which was obviously not justified . The contested decisions constituted a miscarriage of justice since they had granted substantial compensation involving MONEY without there being any legal or factual basis therefor . Consequently , they also breached the interests of the Republic and the decisions had to be rectified .

The applicant subsequently claimed that PERSON should pay back to him the amounts she had received on the basis of the judgment of DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG gave a judgment by which PERSON was obliged to pay these amounts to the applicant . This judgment was not appealed against and became final and enforceable .

On DATE the applicant lodged a request to have enforcement proceedings instituted in respect of this judgment . As he did not pay a fee for the launching of the enforcement proceedings , he was summoned to do so . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant requested the bailiff to return the enforcement order to him . This was done on DATE . As no fee had been paid , the bailiff did not institute enforcement proceedings .
In DATE the applicant requested ORG to take steps in order to have the damage he had sustained as a result of the erroneous judicial decision compensated . He reiterated his request on DATE .
On DATE the applicant wrote a letter to the President of ORG , requesting that the damage he had suffered as a result of the erroneous judicial decision be compensated .

In a reply of DATE , he was informed that the liability of ORG , provided for by LAW , arose only if the fault of the ORG agent was confirmed by a criminal or disciplinary decision . In the light thereof , his request could not be granted .

By a letter of DATE the applicant informed ORG that his efforts to have the damage compensated had proved unsuccessful . He referred to the letter of the President of ORG , relying on LAW . He reiterated that ORG had found that the contested judicial decisions “ constituted a miscarriage of justice since they had granted substantial compensation involving MONEY without there being any legal or factual basis therefor ” . Consequently , they also breached the interests of the Republic and the decisions had to be rectified . He requested that steps be taken in order to have the damage he had suffered compensated .
This letter apparently remained unanswered .

In a letter of DATE the applicant again requested ORG to take steps in order to satisfy his claims for compensation in respect of the damage which he had sustained , having paid to PERSON the sums fixed by the judgment of DATE , which had subsequently been quashed by ORG as being in manifest breach of law .

In reply of DATE the ORG stated that the judgment of ORG did not give rise to any compensation claims against ORG . If the applicant so wished , he could raise his claims in civil proceedings . It would be for the court alone to rule on his claim .
On DATE the applicant reiterated his request to ORG . In a reply of DATE the Ministry referred to its reply of DATE .
Articles CARDINAL et seq . of ORG ( ORG cywilny ) of DATE provide for the ORG ’s liability in tort . In the version applicable until DATE , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . The State Treasury shall be liable for damage caused by a ORG official in the course of carrying out the duties entrusted to him . ”

According to the old case - law of ORG , a plaintiff seeking damages under LAW of LAW had to show that the act in question was unlawful and that the ORG agent had committed a fault ( ORG judgments : No . I PR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL , unpublished , No . I CR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , unpublished and No . I CR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL , unpublished ) .

Under the former LAW , if damage was caused by the ORG official as a result of his / her giving a decision or other official act , ORG was liable only if the giving of the said decision amounted to an infringement of the law which was punishable under criminal law or under any disciplinary regulations , and if the fault of the perpetrator had been confirmed by a judgment of a criminal court or of a competent disciplinary authority , or was otherwise recognised by a superior authority .

Under LAW , everyone is entitled to compensation for damage caused by unlawful acts of a public authority . Pursuant to LAW of the same LAW , a statute shall not bar access to court to persons seeking redress for any breach of their rights or freedoms .
LAW provides that everyone shall have the right to a fair and public hearing of his / her case , without undue delay , before a competent impartial and independent court .

In its judgment of DATE ORG ruled on the compatibility of Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW with LAW . It ruled that LAW was compatible with LAW , if it was so construed as to mean that ORG was liable for damage caused by unlawful acts of public officials in carrying out his / her duties .

In the same judgment the ORG held that LAW was incompatible with LAW in that it placed undue restrictions on access to a court in cases in which the civil liability of the ORG was claimed for acts carried out in the exercise of the ORG powers , other than de facto acts , which were covered by the general principle of LAW ( published in ORG ) , Dz . U. Nr CARDINAL , poz . DATE ) .
The judgment of DATE took effect on DATE . As a result , Article CARDINAL was repealed .
